when_to_say: Used as a general greeting.
example: こんにちは、元気ですか？ (Konnichiwa, genki desu ka?) - Hello, how are you?

when_to_say: Used to express gratitude.
example: ありがとう、助かりました。 (Arigatou, tasukarimashita.) - Thank you, I'm relieved.

when_to_say: Used to apologize or to get someone's attention.
example: すみません、ちょっと失礼します。 (Sumimasen, chotto shitsurei shimasu.) - Excuse me, I'll be right back.

when_to_say: Used to express agreement or understanding.
example: はい、わかりました。 (Hai, wakarimashita.) - Yes, I understand.

when_to_say: Used to express disagreement or negation.
example: いいえ、違います。 (Iie, chigaimasu.) - No, that's wrong.

when_to_say: Used as a morning greeting.
example: おはようございます、今日もいい天気ですね。 (Ohayō gozaimasu, kyō mo ii tenki desu ne.) - Good morning, it's nice weather today.

when_to_say: Used as an afternoon greeting.
example: こんにちは、ご機嫌いかがですか？ (Konnichiwa, gokigen ikaga desu ka?) - Good afternoon, how are you?

when_to_say: Used as an evening greeting.
example: こんばんは、お疲れ様です。 (Konbanwa, otsukaresama desu.) - Good evening, you must be tired.

when_to_say: Used as a polite greeting when meeting someone for the first time.
example: どうぞよろしくお願いします。 (Dōzo yoroshiku onegaishimasu.) - Nice to meet you.

when_to_say: Used to express deep gratitude.
example: 本当にありがとうございます。 (Hontō ni arigatō gozaimasu.) - Thank you very much.

when_to_say: Used to express reassurance or agreement.
example: 大丈夫です、心配しないで。 (Daijōbu desu, shinpai shinaide.) - It's okay, don't worry.

when_to_say: Used to apologize.
example: ごめんなさい、遅れました。 (Gomennasai, okuremashita.) - I'm sorry, I'm late.

word: ありがとうございます
when_to_say: Used to express deep gratitude.
example: 本当にありがとうございます。 (Hontō ni arigatō gozaimasu.) - Thank you very much.

word: すみません、もう一度言ってもらえますか
meaning: excuse me, could you say that again?
when_to_say: Used when you don't understand something.
example: すみません、もう一度言ってもらえますか。 (Sumimasen, mō ichido itte moraemasuka.) - Excuse me, could you say that again?

when_to_say: Used to ask someone to wait briefly.
example: ちょっと待って、すぐ行きます。 (Chotto matte, sugu ikimasu.) - Wait a minute, I'll go right away.

word: ごめんなさい、遅れました
when_to_say: Used to apologize for being late.
example: ごめんなさい、遅れました。 (Gomennasai, okuremashita.) - I'm sorry, I'm late.

when_to_say: Used to express deep gratitude.
example: 本当にありがとうございます。 (Hontō ni arigatō gozaimasu.) - Thank you very much.

word: すみません、ちょっと失礼します
meaning: excuse me, I'll be right back
when_to_say: Used to excuse oneself briefly.
example: すみません、ちょっと失礼します。 (Sumimasen, chotto shitsurei shimasu.) - Excuse me, I'll be right back.

when_to_say: Used to acknowledge understanding.
example: はい、わかりました。 (Hai, wakarimashita.) - Yes, I understand.

when_to_say: Used to express casual gratitude.
example: どうもありがとう、助かりました。 (Dōmo arigatō, tasukarimashita.) - Thanks a lot, I'm relieved.

when_to_say: Used to encourage someone.
example: 頑張ってください。 (Ganbatte kudasai.) - Please do your best.

when_to_say: Used to express reassurance or agreement.
example: 大丈夫です、心配しないで。 (Daijōbu desu, shinpai shinaide.) - It's okay, don't worry.

when_to_say: Used to apologize.
example: ごめんなさい、遅れました。 (Gomennasai, okuremashita.) - I'm sorry, I'm late.

word: ありがとうございます
when_to_say: Used to express deep gratitude.
example: 本当にありがとうございます。 (Hontō ni arigatō gozaimasu.) - Thank you very much.

example: すみません、もう一度言ってもらえますか。 (Sumimasen, mō ichido itte moraemasuka.) - Excuse me, could you say that again?

example: ちょっと待って、すぐ行きます。 (Chotto matte, sugu ikimasu.) - Wait a minute, I'll go right away.

word: すみません、もう一度言ってもらえますか
meaning: excuse me, could you say that again?
when_to_say: Used when you don't understand something.
example: すみません、もう一度言ってもらえますか。 (Sumimasen, mō ichido itte moraemasuka.) - Excuse me, could you say that again?

when_to_say: Used to ask someone to wait briefly.
example: ちょっと待って、すぐ行きます。 (Chotto matte, sugu ikimasu.) - Wait a minute, I'll go right away.

when_to_say: When referring to the previous day.
example: 昨日は何をしましたか？ (Kinō wa nani o shimashita ka?) - What did you do yesterday?

when_to_say: When referring to the current day.
example: 今日は何曜日ですか？ (Kyō wa naniyōbi desu ka?) - What day is it today?

when_to_say: When referring to the next day.
example: 明日は何をしますか？ (Ashita wa nani o shimasu ka?) - What are you going to do tomorrow?

when_to_say: When referring to a specific point in time.
example: 今何時ですか？ (Ima nanji desu ka?) - What time is it now?

when_to_say: When referring to something happening early.
example: 早く寝ましょう。 (Hayaku nemasho.) - Let's go to bed early.

when_to_say: When referring to something happening late.
example: 遅くなりました、すみません。 (Okuremashita, sumimasen.) - I'm late, I'm sorry.

when_to_say: Used to describe a busy schedule.
example: 最近、とても忙しいです。 (Saikin, totemo isogashii desu.) - I've been very busy lately.

when_to_say: Used to express tiredness.
example: 今日は疲れたので、早く寝ます。 (Kyō wa tsukaretano de, hayaku nemasu.) - I'm tired today, so I'll go to bed early.

when_to_say: Used to describe something enjoyable.
example: 今日はとても楽しいです。 (Kyō wa totemo tanoshii desu.) - Today is very fun.

when_to_say: Used to express sadness.
example: 私は悲しいです。 (Watashi wa kanashii desu.) - I'm sad.

when_to_say: Used to express the action of eating.
example: 私はご飯を食べます。 (Watashi wa gohan o tabemasu.) - I eat rice.

when_to_say: Used to express the action of drinking.
example: 私は水を飲みます。 (Watashi wa mizu o nomimasu.) - I drink water.

when_to_say: Used to express the action of going to a place.
example: 私は学校に行きます。 (Watashi wa gakkō ni ikimasu.) - I go to school.

when_to_say: Used to express the action of coming to a place.
example: 友達が家に来ます。 (Tomodachi ga ie ni kimasu.) - My friend is coming to my house.

when_to_say: Used to express the action of seeing something.
example: 私はテレビを見ます。 (Watashi wa terebi o mimasu.) - I watch TV.

when_to_say: Used to express the action of hearing or listening to something.
example: 私は音楽を聞きます。 (Watashi wa ongaku o kikimasu.) - I listen to music.

when_to_say: Used to refer to a written work.
example: 私は本を読みます。 (Watashi wa hon o yomimasu.) - I read books.

when_to_say: Used to refer to a place of residence.
example: 私は家にいます。 (Watashi wa ie ni imasu.) - I am at home.

when_to_say: Used to refer to an educational institution.
example: 私は学校に行きます。 (Watashi wa gakkō ni ikimasu.) - I go to school.

when_to_say: Used to refer to one's occupation.
example: 私は仕事に行きます。 (Watashi wa shigoto ni ikimasu.) - I go to work.

when_to_say: Used to refer to one's occupation.
example: 私は仕事に行きます。 (Watashi wa shigoto ni ikimasu.) - I go to work.

when_to_say: Used to refer to academic study.
example: 私は勉強します。 (Watashi wa benkyō shimasu.) - I study.

when_to_say: Used to refer to a person one is friendly with.
example: 友達と遊びます。 (Tomodachi to asobimasu.) - I play with my friend.

when_to_say: Used to refer to one's family.
example: 家族と食事をします。 (Kazoku to shokuji o shimasu.) - I eat with my family.

when_to_say: Used to refer to a canine.
example: 犬が好きです。 (Inu ga suki desu.) - I like dogs.

when_to_say: Used to refer to a feline.
example: 猫がかわいいです。 (Neko ga kawaii desu.) - Cats are cute.

when_to_say: Used to refer to a motor vehicle.
example: 車で出かけます。 (Kuruma de dekakemasu.) - I go out by car.

when_to_say: Used to refer to a railway vehicle.
example: 電車に乗ります。 (Densha ni norimasu.) - I ride the train.

when_to_say: Used to describe something that is hard to do or understand.
example: この漢字は難しいです。 (Kono kanji wa muzukashii desu.) - This kanji is difficult.

when_to_say: Used to describe something that is easy to do or understand.
example: この問題は簡単です。 (Kono mondai wa kantan desu.) - This problem is easy.

when_to_say: Used to describe something that is enjoyable or captivating.
example: この映画は面白いです。 (Kono eiga wa omoshiroi desu.) - This movie is interesting.

when_to_say: Used to express liking something or someone.
example: 私は猫が好きです。 (Watashi wa neko ga suki desu.) - I like cats.

when_to_say: Used to express disliking something or someone.
example: 私はピーマンが嫌いです。 (Watashi wa pīman ga kirai desu.) - I dislike bell peppers.

when_to_say: Used to express happiness.
example: プレゼントをもらって嬉しいです。 (Purezento o moratte ureshii desu.) - I'm happy to receive a present.

when_to_say: Used to express sadness.
example: 私は悲しいです。 (Watashi wa kanashii desu.) - I'm sad.

when_to_say: Used to describe a hot temperature.
example: 今日は暑いです。 (Kyō wa atsui desu.) - It's hot today.

when_to_say: Used to describe a cold temperature.
example: 今日は寒いです。 (Kyō wa samui desu.) - It's cold today.

when_to_say: Used to describe something that tastes good.
example: このラーメンは美味しいです。 (Kono rāmen wa oishii desu.) - This ramen is delicious.

when_to_say: Used to describe something that is hard to do or understand.
example: この漢字は難しいです。 (Kono kanji wa muzukashii desu.) - This kanji is difficult.

when_to_say: Used to describe something that is easy to do or understand.
example: この問題は簡単です。 (Kono mondai wa kantan desu.) - This problem is easy.

when_to_say: Used to describe something that is easy to use or helpful.
example: このアプリは便利です。 (Kono app wa benri desu.) - This app is convenient.

when_to_say: Used to describe something that is beautiful or clean.
example: 花が綺麗です。 (Hana ga kirei desu.) - The flower is beautiful.

when_to_say: Used to describe something that is dirty or unclean.
example: この服は汚いです。 (Kono fuku wa kitanai desu.) - This clothes is dirty.

when_to_say: Used to describe something that is expensive.
example: このバッグは高いです。 (Kono baggu wa takai desu.) - This bag is expensive.

when_to_say: Used to describe something that is cheap.
example: この本は安いです。 (Kono hon wa yasui desu.) - This book is cheap.

when_to_say: Used to describe something that tastes good.
example: このラーメンは美味しいです。 (Kono rāmen wa oishii desu.) - This ramen is delicious.

when_to_say: Used to describe something that tastes bad.
example: この料理はまずいです。 (Kono ryōri wa mazuidesu.) - This dish is bad.

when_to_say: Used to describe something that is easy to use or helpful.
example: このアプリは便利です。 (Kono app wa benri desu.) - This app is convenient.

when_to_say: Used to describe something that is beautiful or clean.
example: 花が綺麗です。 (Hana ga kirei desu.) - The flower is beautiful.

when_to_say: Used to describe something that is dirty or unclean.
example: この服は汚いです。 (Kono fuku wa kitanai desu.) - This clothes is dirty.

when_to_say: Used to describe something that is expensive.
example: このバッグは高いです。 (Kono baggu wa takai desu.) - This bag is expensive.

when_to_say: Used to describe something that is hard to do or understand.
example: この漢字は難しいです。 (Kono kanji wa muzukashii desu.) - This kanji is difficult.

when_to_say: Used to describe something that is easy to do or understand.
example: この問題は簡単です。 (Kono mondai wa kantan desu.) - This problem is easy.

when_to_say: Used to describe something that is intricate or involved.
example: この問題はとても複雑です。 (Kono mondai wa totemo fukuzatsu desu.) - This problem is very complicated.

when_to_say: Used to describe something that is theoretical or conceptual.
example: 哲学的な考え方は抽象的です。 (Tetsugakuteki na kangaekata wa chūshōteki desu.) - Philosophical thinking is abstract.

when_to_say: Used to describe something that is unclear or indefinite.
example: 彼の発言は曖昧でよくわかりませんでした。 (Kare no hatsugen wa aimaide yoku wakarimasen deshita.) - His statement was ambiguous and I didn't understand it well.

when_to_say: Used to refer to a situation where two or more things are incompatible.
example: 彼の言動には矛盾があります。 (Kare no gendō ni wa mujun ga arimasu.) - There is a contradiction in his words and actions.

when_to_say: Used to describe something that is difficult to perceive or express.
example: この料理の味は微妙です。 (Kono ryōri no aji wa bimyo desu.) - The taste of this dish is subtle.

when_to_say: Used to refer to something that is not real or based on reality.
example: 彼は幻想に囚われていました。 (Kare wa gensō ni torawarete imashita.) - He was obsessed with illusions.

when_to_say: Used to refer to a situation where two or more things are incompatible.
example: 彼の言動には矛盾があります。 (Kare no gendō ni wa mujun ga arimasu.) - There is a contradiction in his words and actions.

when_to_say: Used to describe something that is unclear or indefinite.
example: 彼の発言は曖昧でよくわかりませんでした。 (Kare no hatsugen wa aimaide yoku wakarimasen deshita.) - His statement was ambiguous and I didn't understand it well.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the study of fundamental questions about existence, knowledge, values, reason, mind, and language.
example: 彼は哲学を専攻しています。 (Kare wa tetsugaku o senkō shite imasu.) - He majors in philosophy.

when_to_say: Used to refer to moral principles that govern a person's behavior or the conducting of an activity.
example: 彼は高い倫理観を持っています。 (Kare wa takai rinrikan o motte imasu.) - He has a high sense of ethics.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the branch of philosophy dealing with the nature of beauty, art, taste, and with the creation or appreciation of beauty.
example: 彼女は美学に興味を持っています。 (Kanojo wa bigaku ni kyōmi o motte imasu.) - She is interested in aesthetics.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the scientific study of the human mind and its functions, especially those affecting behavior in a given context.
example: 彼女は心理学を勉強しています。 (Kanojo wa shinrigaku o benkyō shite imasu.) - She is studying psychology.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the study of society, human social relationships and institutions.
example: 彼は社会学の教授です。 (Kare wa shakaigaku no kyōju desu.) - He is a professor of sociology.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the systematic study of government and politics.
example: 彼女は政治学に興味を持っています。 (Kanojo wa seijigaku ni kyōmi o motte imasu.) - She is interested in political science.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the study of the production, distribution, and consumption of goods and services.
example: 彼は経済学を専攻しています。 (Kare wa keizaigaku o senkō shite imasu.) - He majors in economics.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the study of past events, particularly in human affairs.
example: 彼女は歴史学の研究者です。 (Kanojo wa rekishigaku no kenkyūsha desu.) - She is a historian.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the branch of science concerned with the nature and properties of matter and energy.
example: 彼は物理学の教授です。 (Kare wa butsurigaku no kyōju desu.) - He is a professor of physics.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the scientific study of the properties and behavior of matter.
example: 彼女は化学の実験をしています。 (Kanojo wa kagaku no jikken o shite imasu.) - She is doing a chemistry experiment.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the scientific study of life and living organisms.
example: 彼は生物学の研究者です。 (Kare wa seibutsu-gaku no kenkyūsha desu.) - He is a biologist.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the abstract science of number, quantity, and space.
example: 彼女は数学が得意です。 (Kanojo wa sūgaku ga tokui desu.) - She is good at math.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the scientific study of celestial objects and phenomena.
example: 彼は天文学に興味を持っています。 (Kare wa tenmongaku ni kyōmi o motte imasu.) - He is interested in astronomy.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the scientific study of the Earth's material composition, structure, processes, and history.
example: 彼女は地質学の研究者です。 (Kanojo wa chishitsugaku no kenkyūsha desu.) - She is a geologist.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the scientific study of the atmosphere and weather processes.
example: 彼は気象学の専門家です。 (Kare wa kishōgaku no senmongaka desu.) - He is a meteorologist.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the scientific study of the ocean and its phenomena.
example: 彼女は海洋学に興味を持っています。 (Kanojo wa kaiyōgaku ni kyōmi o motte imasu.) - She is interested in oceanography.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the application of scientific and mathematical principles to practical problems.
example: 彼は工学の博士号を持っています。 (Kare wa kōgaku no hakushi-gō o motte imasu.) - He has a doctorate in engineering.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the science or practice of the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of disease.
example: 彼女は医学部に通っています。 (Kanojo wa igakubu ni tōtte imasu.) - She is attending medical school.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the study and practice of law.
example: 彼は法律学の専門家です。 (Kare wa hōgaku no senmongaka desu.) - He is a legal expert.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the study of the production, distribution, and consumption of goods and services.
example: 彼は経済学を専攻しています。 (Kare wa keizaigaku o senkō shite imasu.) - He majors in economics.

example: この問題はとても複雑です。 (Kono mondai wa totemo fukuzatsu desu.) - This problem is very complicated.
